ygData.subject: Re: Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)
ygData.msgSnippet: You could also force symmetry along one axis by removing the usual CPPN input (e.g. x ) and replacing it with Gauss(x).  Then evolution would have no choice

You could also force symmetry along one axis by removing the usual CPPN i=
nput (e.g. "x") and replacing it with Gauss(x).  Then evolution would have =
no choice but to work with symmetry.  It would be interesting to see if thi=
ngs do any better with such a constraint.

Best,

ken

--- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, "martin_pyka" <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
>
> ok, and would you say, =
that a sphere provides a better starting point for evolving bilateral symme=
tric organisms than other starting points? I suppose that this should be th=
e case. However, it could be that the objective search favors occasionally =
deceptive stepping stones (with regard to symmetrical objects).
> 
> On the=
 other hand, we have to admit that this is just a property that would be ni=
ce to see in the evolutionary search. We don't know, whether organisms with=
 a high degree of symmetry would really outperform the organisms that you f=
ound.
> 
> Best,
> Martin
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <=
jclune@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Martin,
> > 
> > The CPPNs we used have a distan=
ce from center output. So they are easily able to make spheres in the cente=
r of the bounding box (by just using that input and ignoring x, y, and z). =
We often saw spherical "rollers" that dropped and expanded part of their sp=
here to push them away from the origin. So there is nothing in principle th=
at prevented them from elaborating on a symmetrical, spherical starting poi=
nt.  
> > 
> >

ote:

> > > > > That certainly makes sense. It raises the question of h=
ow bilateral symmetry arose in biological organisms.
> > > 
> > > I have no=
 link to literature or any kind of evidence, but with regard to this paper =
I was wondering what kind of creatures would emerge if you would start with=
 an organism that has spherical symmetry (as far as you can represent spher=
ical symmetry with voxels ;)) encoded through a CPPN. This ancestor organis=
m would be something like a unicellular organism in nature. Starting with a=
 CPPN of such an organism would mean that radial and bilateral symmetry is =
in actual fact a departure from spherical symmetry. And I suspect that from=
 this starting position bilateral symmetry should be easier to reach (and i=
t is maybe biologically more plausible!?).
> > > 
> > > @Jeff: can you try =
that for us? :-)
> > > 
> > > From this perspective, complexification (or d=
iversification) would mean breaking the symmetry rather than approaching it=
, which seems to me more natural. But as I said, I am not familiar with the=
 literature in this area.
> > > 
> > > Best,
> > > Martin
> > > 
> > >
